atDirectives.name: @theme
atDirectives.description: Use the `@theme` directive to define your project's custom design tokens, like fonts, colors, and breakpoints.

atDirectives.name: @source
atDirectives.description: Use the `@source` directive to explicitly specify source files that aren't picked up by Tailwind's automatic content detection.

atDirectives.name: @utility
atDirectives.description: Use the `@utility` directive to add custom utilities to your project that work with variants like `hover`, `focus` and `lg`.

atDirectives.name: @variant
atDirectives.description: Use the `@variant` directive to apply a Tailwind variant to styles in your CSS.

atDirectives.name: @custom-variant
atDirectives.description: Use the `@custom-variant` directive to add a custom variant in your project.

atDirectives.name: @apply
atDirectives.description: Use the `@apply` directive to inline any existing utility classes into your own custom CSS.

atDirectives.name: @reference
atDirectives.description:
If you want to use `@apply` or `@variant` in the `<style>` block of a Vue or Svelte component, or within CSS modules, you will need to import your theme variables, custom utilities, and custom variants to make those values available in that context.

To do this without duplicating any CSS in your output, use the `@reference` directive to import your main stylesheet for reference without actually including the styles.

atDirectives.name: @config
atDirectives.description: Use the `@config` directive to load a legacy JavaScript-based configuration file.

atDirectives.name: @plugin
atDirectives.description: Use the `@plugin` directive to load a legacy JavaScript-based plugin.
